sections.content: Wendy's changed the social media game when they began treating their Twitter/X account like it was a real person posting instead of a PR department. They joked around, roasted competitors, responded to followers, and leaned fully into a tone that was really uncommon in traditional advertising.
Poking fun at competitors wasn't necessarily a new idea, but their method was an unusual approach in the medium of social media.

sections.caption: Wendy's signature roasting style on social media

items: It aligned with internal brand changes (improving wages, being more transparent about pricing)
It kept Wendy's constantly in the public conversation

sections.content: Their social voice amplified their brand and brought attention to real business changes happening behind the scenes.

Social media is a powerful tool that allows you to remain relevant online and constantly engage with your customer base. How you choose to do that is up to you (and your PR department), but most angles can be successful if you're publicly accessible to your audience.

items: Social media is a **two-way engagement platform**, not just a billboard
"Corporate voice" is no longer the only option
Being accessible can increase positive sentiment
People treat brand accounts like people they can talk to
